prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Three Epochs of Band 3 Detection: GX 339-4
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
This science goal aims to provide a >20 sigma detection of the flux in Band 3 of GX339-4, a transient black hole X-ray binary, when it is in the rising hard state. The strong detection is needed to accurately construct a spectral index from Band 3, Band 6, and Band 7. The flux is expected to arise from (continuum) synchrotron emission.
The total request is for this science goal to be performed 3 times (i.e., 3 x 4.1 min on source and 3 x 29.4 minutes total estimated time).
We request 3 epochs of Band 3 detections, where each epoch is taken within 7-21 days of the previous epoch and that Band 6 and Band 7 science goals for the same epoch are taken as close together in time as possible.

prj:VisitConstraint.prj:note:
We ask that the first epoch observation be taken within 14 days of our triggering of this ToO and that data for each of three epochs of Science Goals are taken as close together as possible.
We request that each epoch be taken within 7-21 days of the previous epoch.
Our trigger criteria for GX 339-4 is that it is in the rising hard state as measured by X-ray satellites (e.g., Swift or MAXI) and that there is a 6 GHz radio detection at 1 mJy.

We ask that the first epoch observation be taken within 14 days of our triggering of this ToO and that data for each of three epochs of Science Goals are taken as close together as possible.
We request that each epoch be taken within 7-21 days of the previous epoch.
Our trigger criteria for GX 339-4 is that it is in the rising hard state as measured by X-ray satellites (e.g., Swift or MAXI) and that there is a 6 GHz radio detection at 1 mJy.

We ask that the first epoch observation be taken within 14 days of our triggering of this ToO and that data for each of three epochs of Science Goals are taken as close together as possible.
We request that each epoch be taken within 7-21 days of the previous epoch.
Our trigger criteria for GX 339-4 is that it is in the rising hard state as measured by X-ray satellites (e.g., Swift or MAXI) and that there is a 6 GHz radio detection at 1 mJy.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our primary science goals require an accurate measurement of the sub-mm spectral index of a BHXRB in outburst for all expected radio to sub-mm spectral indices (0>\alpha_{6-350 GHz} > 1). By requiring that \delta \alpha_{85-350 GHz} ~ 0.05, we ensure that extrapolating the sub-mm normalization and index down to radio frequencies (6 GHz) will retain >5 \sigma accuracy. We chose central frequencies in Band 3 (92 GHz), Band 6 (221 GHz), \& Band 7 (343 GHz) that balance a broad spectral coverage with achieving low system temperatures. In continuum mode, we will cover 84-88 GHz, 96-100 GHz, 211-215 GHz, 227-231 GHz, 335-339 GHz, & 347-351 GHz. Extensive simulations indicate that we require 20\sigma detections in Bands 3, 6, & 7 to achieve our spectral index accuracy.
Given this SNR and that the source is unlikely to be resolved, neither uv-coverage nor array configuration are issues. This sets a 0.05 mJy RMS requirement for each of our three science goals (one per band).
In the case of Bands 3 and 6, our projected overheads account for ~40% of the total time. This arises from our relatively short on-source required times. To achieve <30% overheads we would require ~14 and 11 extra minutes per epoch in Bands 3 and 6, respectively, (and would achieve ~30 muJy and 34 muJy RMS). As this would result in a total of 150 minutes of added time to the proposal,goes beyond our required precision, and would make scheduling more difficult, we chose to forgo the extra sensitivity to achieve the 30% overhead goal.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Three Epochs of Band 3 Detection: Decaying Hard State BHXRB (TBD)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
This science goal aims to provide a >20 sigma detection of the flux in Band 3 of the next radio-bright transient black hole X-ray binary, when it is in the decaying hard state. The strong detection is needed to accurately construct a spectral index from Band 3, Band 6, and Band 7. The flux is expected to arise from (continuum) synchrotron emission.
The total request is for this science goal to be performed 3 times (i.e., 3 x 3.9 min on source and 3 x 29.2 minutes total estimated time).
We request 3 epochs of Band 3 detections, where each epoch is taken within 7-21 days of the previous epoch and that Band 6 and Band 7 science goals for the same epoch are taken as close together in time as possible.

prj:VisitConstraint.prj:note:
We ask that the first epoch observation be taken within 14 days of our triggering of this ToO and that data for each of three epochs of Science Goals are taken as close together as possible.
We request that each epoch be taken within 7 - 21 days of the previous epoch.
Our trigger criteria for the decaying hard state Black Hole X-ray binary is that it is in the decaying hard state as measured by X-ray satellites (e.g., Swift or MAXI) and that there is a 6 GHz radio detection at 2 mJy (to allow for decay between trigger and observations).

Our primary science goals require an accurate measurement of the sub-mm spectral index of a BHXRB in outburst for all expected radio to sub-mm spectral indices (0>\alpha_{6-350 GHz} > 1). prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
Black Hole X-ray binaries (BHXRBs) are crucial laboratories for relativity and high energy astrophysics. BHXRBs cycle through different accretion states on timescales of days to months, providing a time-resolved view of how matter behaves in a strong gravity environment. In particular, the onset and decline of a transient XRB outburst is signalled by hard X-ray emission and a steady, compact relativistic jet. Broad-band spectral measurements of jet emission in Galactic XRBs can constrain the physical conditions of the jet near a BH, address the efficiency with which BHs grow, and answer what happens when the energy in an accretion flow is not just radiated away, but instead mechanically transported.
The few BHXRBs observed in the sub-mm regime, which bridges a crucial gap between radio and IR, have been surprisingly bright. We propose 2 sets of 3 ToO observations targeting the BHXRB GX3394 and the next radio-bright BHXRB in the decaying hard state to accurately measure the sub-mm normalization and spectral index, constrain the sub-mm behaviour of BHXRBs in outburst, and directly test if their sub-mm fluxes are anomalously high or consistent with time-dependent jet models.
